PostValue.explanation: This is a practical hiring announcement for a small, EA-aligned org. It could modestly increase Probably Good’s capacity to help people find impactful careers (useful to job-seekers and the EA talent pipeline), but it’s not a foundational argument or evidence that would shift major EA strategies. For general humanity it’s effectively trivial—useful only to a tiny, specific audience and unlikely to have broad impact.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) No compensation / seniority / contract clarity — add a salary band (or at least FTE range), contract type (permanent vs fixed-term), expected hours / FTE, and seniority level. EA readers strongly prefer pay transparency and this materially affects who applies. Actionable: include a salary range (e.g. “£40k–£55k FTE / pro rata for part-time”), whether the role is permanent, and whether you expect full-time or part-time.  

2) Unclear location/eligibility/timezone and visa policy — say explicitly whether you hire globally, whether candidates must be able to work UK/Europe hours, and whether you can sponsor visas. This avoids wasting applicants’ time and increases applicant quality. Actionable: add one sentence like “We hire remotely worldwide; applicants must be able to overlap 3–4 hours with UK time (BST) / we cannot sponsor work visas” (or the true policy). Also give an expected start date and outline the timeline after the deadline.  

3) Ambiguous role scope, authority, and success metrics — the Head of Growth title implies leadership but the description reads hands-on. Candidates need clarity on reporting lines, management responsibility, decision authority (budget/strategy), and immediate priorities. Actionable: add 2–3 bullet points for each role describing (a) who the role reports to, (b) whether they will manage staff or contractors, (c) the top 3 goals for the first 3–6 months, and (d) concrete success metrics (e.g. X% increase in lead volume, Y conversion rate improvement, or operational SLA targets).  

Addressing these three items will significantly reduce unqualified or confused applications and improve conversion of high-quality candidates.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback hits the major, practical omissions that matter a lot to applicants (pay band, FTE/contract type, timezone/visa policy, and clearer scope/authority/metrics). These are the kinds of ‘own-goal’ items that reduce application quality and deter good candidates—especially in the EA community where pay transparency is expected. Implementing them would significantly improve the post with only a small increase in length. It’s not a 10 because the post’s core offer isn’t wrong, but these are critical fixes the author should make.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No clear or widely recognized person/pen-name 'Probably Good' in EA or rationalist communities or in broader public discourse based on available information. Likely a pseudonymous/low-profile online handle; please provide links or more context if you want a re-evaluation.

PostClarity.explanation: Very clear and easy to follow: purpose, roles, responsibilities, and deadline are presented in a well-structured, concise way with helpful links. Minor weaknesses: some marketing-y repetition and a few missing specifics that affect decisiveness (salary range, seniority level/hours, timezone expectations), but those don't substantially harm overall clarity.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is a routine hiring announcement for two operational/marketing roles at an EA-adjacent org. For EA Forum readers, similar posts (orgs recruiting, remote roles, growth/ops positions, flexible hiring) are common; the only slightly uncommon details are the specific mix of responsibilities and explicit mention of tools like Claude/Airtable/Zapier. For the general public it’s entirely ordinary — job ads with similar descriptions are ubiquitous, so there’s effectively no novelty.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: This is primarily a hiring announcement rather than an argument-driven post. The claims are clear and the roles are described in concrete terms (responsibilities, tools, flexibility), so the reasoning is straightforward and well-structured for its purpose. However, there is little to no empirical evidence or justification that these hires are needed or will succeed at scaling impact (no metrics, no rationale for timing, no compensation or team context, no evidence of past hiring outcomes). For an announcement that mainly aims to attract applicants the level of detail is acceptable, but as support for the broader claim that these hires will help more people build impactful careers the evidence is weak.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Major empirical claims in the post are well-supported: the EA Forum announcement exists and matches the text (including the 27 July deadline), and independent job-board copies of the two role descriptions (Operations Specialist; Marketer / Head of Growth) corroborate the responsibilities, tools, and timelines. The organization’s contact email (team@probablygood.org) and site are also confirmed. Minor issues: some job-board copies show a 28 July closing date (one secondary site) and the Ashby-hosted job pages require JavaScript so their raw HTML wasn’t viewable; Probably Good’s 'Work with us' page now states they are not currently hiring (likely reflecting the roles closing after the July deadline). These small discrepancies don’t materially contradict the post’s core claims.
